LEAD: The United States Department of Energy will begin ''a major export initiative'' to help American oil-service companies gain business abroad, W. Henson Moore, the Deputy Energy Secretary, said today.
The United States Department of Energy will begin ''a major export initiative'' to help American oil-service companies gain business abroad, W. Henson Moore, the Deputy Energy Secretary, said today.

Mr. Moore, speaking at the World Energy Conference here, said the Government would seek to ''assist American business in identifying opportunities and overcoming barriers to effective competition in international projects.''
The American oil-service industry has shrunk sharply since the collapse of oil prices in 1986 nearly closed the drilling business.

Mr. Moore also repeated President Bush's pledge to cut sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons a year, a sensitive point in eastern Canada, where the emissions have been proven to cause acid rain.
He said he expected the President's clean air package to pass Congress, but added: ''Is it going to be quick? No. Is it going to be easy? No. Is it going to emerge unchanged? Probably not.''
